slides.title: Welcome to Environmental Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Environmental Chemistry

Welcome to **Environmental Chemistry** - the study of chemical processes in the environment!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Air Pollution** - Causes and effects
- **Water Pollution** - Contamination sources
- **Soil Pollution** - Land degradation
- **Greenhouse Effect** - Climate change chemistry
- **Ozone Layer** - Protection and depletion
- **Green Chemistry** - Sustainable solutions

> **Fun Fact:** Every chemical reaction affects the environment in some way!

## Why Environmental Chemistry Matters:
- Understanding pollution
- Developing solutions
- Protecting ecosystems
- Sustainable development
- Human health

slides.title: Air Pollution
slides.content:
# Air Pollution

## Major Air Pollutants:

| Pollutant | Source | Effects |
|-----------|--------|--------|
| CO | Incomplete combustion | Binds hemoglobin |
| SO2 | Burning fossil fuels | Acid rain, respiratory |
| NOx | Vehicles, power plants | Smog, acid rain |
| O3 (ground) | Photochemical reactions | Respiratory damage |
| Particulates | Industry, vehicles | Lung disease |

## Carbon Monoxide (CO):
```
2C + O2 -> 2CO (incomplete)
```
- Binds to hemoglobin 200x stronger than O2
- Prevents oxygen transport

## Sulfur Dioxide:
```
S + O2 -> SO2
SO2 + H2O -> H2SO3 (acid rain)
```

## Nitrogen Oxides:
```
N2 + O2 -> 2NO (high temp)
2NO + O2 -> 2NO2
```

## Photochemical Smog:
- NO2 + sunlight -> NO + O
- O + O2 -> O3 (ground level ozone)
- Harmful to lungs and plants

slides.title: Water Pollution
slides.content:
# Water Pollution

## Types of Pollutants:

| Type | Examples | Source |
|------|----------|--------|
| Organic | Sewage, oil | Domestic, industry |
| Inorganic | Heavy metals, acids | Mining, factories |
| Thermal | Hot water discharge | Power plants |
| Microbial | Bacteria, viruses | Sewage |
| Nutrients | Nitrates, phosphates | Agriculture |

## Eutrophication:

1. Excess nutrients enter water
2. Algae bloom
3. Algae die and decompose
4. Bacteria use oxygen
5. Fish and organisms die

## BOD and COD:

**BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand):**
Oxygen needed by microbes to decompose organic matter.

**COD (Chemical Oxygen Demand):**
Oxygen needed for chemical oxidation.

## Heavy Metal Pollution:

| Metal | Source | Health Effect |
|-------|--------|---------------|
| Hg | Mining, industry | Brain damage |
| Pb | Pipes, paint | Neurological |
| Cd | Batteries | Kidney damage |
| As | Groundwater | Cancer |

slides.quizQuestion: What is the main cause of eutrophication?

slides.title: Soil Pollution
slides.content:
# Soil Pollution

## Sources:

| Source | Pollutants |
|--------|------------|
| Agriculture | Pesticides, fertilizers |
| Industry | Heavy metals, chemicals |
| Mining | Toxic waste, acids |
| Landfills | Leachate |
| Radioactive | Nuclear waste |

## Pesticides:

**Types:**
- Insecticides (kill insects)
- Herbicides (kill plants)
- Fungicides (kill fungi)

**Problems:**
- Bioaccumulation
- Persistence in environment
- Effects on non-target species

## Heavy Metals in Soil:

- Cannot be degraded
- Accumulate in organisms
- Enter food chain

## Acid Mine Drainage:

```
2FeS2 + 7O2 + 2H2O -> 2FeSO4 + 2H2SO4
```

Sulfuric acid formation from exposed sulfide minerals.

## Remediation:

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| Bioremediation | Microbes degrade pollutants |
| Phytoremediation | Plants absorb pollutants |
| Excavation | Remove contaminated soil |

slides.title: Greenhouse Effect
slides.content:
# Greenhouse Effect

## Natural Greenhouse Effect:

1. Sun's energy reaches Earth
2. Earth absorbs and re-emits as infrared
3. Greenhouse gases trap some heat
4. Keeps Earth warm (about 15 C vs -18 C)

## Greenhouse Gases:

| Gas | Source | GWP* |
|-----|--------|------|
| CO2 | Fossil fuels, respiration | 1 |
| CH4 | Agriculture, landfills | 28 |
| N2O | Fertilizers, industry | 265 |
| CFCs | Refrigerants | 1000s |
| H2O | Evaporation | - |

*GWP = Global Warming Potential (100-year)

## Enhanced Greenhouse Effect:

- Human activities increase greenhouse gases
- More heat trapped
- Global temperature rising

## CO2 Sources:

```
C + O2 -> CO2 (combustion)
```

- Fossil fuel burning (biggest source)
- Deforestation
- Cement production

## Effects:
- Rising temperatures
- Sea level rise
- Extreme weather
- Ecosystem changes

slides.title: Climate Change
slides.content:
# Climate Change

## Evidence:

| Evidence | Observation |
|----------|-------------|
| Temperature | +1 C since 1900 |
| Sea level | +20 cm since 1900 |
| Ice sheets | Decreasing mass |
| Arctic ice | Decreasing area |
| CO2 levels | 420 ppm (was 280) |

## Carbon Cycle:

**Natural sources/sinks:**
- Photosynthesis (removes CO2)
- Respiration (produces CO2)
- Ocean absorption
- Decomposition

**Human disruption:**
- Fossil fuels add ancient carbon
- Deforestation reduces absorption

## Carbon Footprint:

Total greenhouse gases produced by an activity.

## Solutions:

| Approach | Examples |
|----------|----------|
| Renewable energy | Solar, wind, hydro |
| Efficiency | Better insulation, LEDs |
| Carbon capture | CCS technology |
| Reforestation | Plant trees |
| Policy | Carbon tax, emissions trading |

slides.quizQuestion: Which gas has the highest Global Warming Potential?

slides.title: Ozone Layer
slides.content:
# Ozone Layer

## Ozone in Atmosphere:

**Stratospheric ozone (good):**
- 15-35 km altitude
- Absorbs UV radiation
- Protects life on Earth

**Tropospheric ozone (bad):**
- Ground level
- Component of smog
- Harmful to breathe

## Ozone Formation:

```
O2 + UV -> 2O (atoms)
O + O2 -> O3
```

## Ozone Destruction:

```
O3 + UV -> O2 + O
O + O3 -> 2O2
```

## CFC Damage:

```
CFCl3 + UV -> CFCl2 + Cl
Cl + O3 -> ClO + O2
ClO + O -> Cl + O2
```

One Cl atom destroys ~100,000 O3 molecules!

## Ozone Hole:

- Over Antarctica
- Discovered 1985
- Caused by CFCs
- Montreal Protocol (1987) banned CFCs
- Slowly recovering

slides.title: Acid Rain
slides.content:
# Acid Rain

## Formation:

### Sulfuric Acid:
```
SO2 + H2O -> H2SO3
2SO2 + O2 -> 2SO3
SO3 + H2O -> H2SO4
```

### Nitric Acid:
```
4NO2 + O2 + 2H2O -> 4HNO3
```

## pH of Acid Rain:

- Normal rain: pH 5.6
- Acid rain: pH < 5.0
- Severely acidic: pH 4.0-4.5

## Effects:

| Target | Damage |
|--------|--------|
| Lakes | Fish die, ecosystem changes |
| Forests | Leaf damage, soil leaching |
| Buildings | Limestone erodes |
| Metals | Corrosion |
| Health | Respiratory issues |

## Solutions:

- Scrubbers on power plants
- Low-sulfur fuels
- Catalytic converters
- Renewable energy

## Neutralization:

```
H2SO4 + CaCO3 -> CaSO4 + H2O + CO2
```

Liming lakes and soils can help.

slides.title: Green Chemistry
slides.content:
# Green Chemistry

**Green Chemistry** = designing products/processes to reduce hazards.

## 12 Principles:

| # | Principle |
|---|----------|
| 1 | Prevention (better than cleanup) |
| 2 | Atom economy (maximize atoms in product) |
| 3 | Less hazardous synthesis |
| 4 | Safer chemicals |
| 5 | Safer solvents |
| 6 | Energy efficiency |
| 7 | Renewable feedstocks |
| 8 | Reduce derivatives |
| 9 | Catalysis (better than stoichiometric) |
| 10 | Design for degradation |
| 11 | Real-time analysis |
| 12 | Inherently safer chemistry |

## Examples:

**Water as solvent:**
- Safer than organic solvents
- Non-flammable
- Non-toxic

**Supercritical CO2:**
- Replaces organic solvents
- Non-toxic, recyclable
- Used in dry cleaning, extraction

**Bioplastics:**
- From renewable sources
- Biodegradable

## Atom Economy:

```
% Atom economy = (MW of product / MW of reactants) x 100
```

Higher is better - more atoms end up in product.

slides.quizQuestion: What is the first principle of green chemistry?

slides.title: Water Treatment
slides.content:
# Water Treatment

## Drinking Water Treatment:

| Stage | Process |
|-------|--------|
| 1 | Screening (remove large debris) |
| 2 | Coagulation (add Al2(SO4)3) |
| 3 | Flocculation (particles clump) |
| 4 | Sedimentation (settle) |
| 5 | Filtration (sand, carbon) |
| 6 | Disinfection (Cl2, O3, UV) |

## Wastewater Treatment:

**Primary:** Physical settling
**Secondary:** Biological (activated sludge)
**Tertiary:** Advanced (nutrient removal)

## Disinfection:

| Method | Advantages | Disadvantages |
|--------|------------|---------------|
| Chlorination | Effective, cheap | Byproducts |
| Ozone | No residual | Expensive |
| UV | No chemicals | No residual |

## Chlorination:

```
Cl2 + H2O -> HOCl + HCl
```

HOCl kills microorganisms.

## Water Quality Tests:

| Parameter | Significance |
|-----------|-------------|
| pH | Acidity/alkalinity |
| BOD | Organic pollution |
| Dissolved O2 | Aquatic life |
| Turbidity | Suspended particles |
| Coliform | Microbial contamination |

slides.title: Waste Management
slides.content:
# Waste Management

## Waste Hierarchy:

1. **Prevent** - Best option
2. **Reduce** - Use less
3. **Reuse** - Use again
4. **Recycle** - Make new products
5. **Recover** - Energy from waste
6. **Dispose** - Landfill (last resort)

## Types of Waste:

| Type | Examples |
|------|----------|
| Municipal | Household garbage |
| Industrial | Factory waste |
| Hazardous | Chemicals, batteries |
| Radioactive | Nuclear waste |
| E-waste | Electronics |

## Recycling:

| Material | Recycles to |
|----------|-------------|
| Paper | New paper, cardboard |
| Glass | New glass |
| Metals | New metal products |
| Plastics | Various (by type) |

## Hazardous Waste:

**Characteristics:**
- Ignitable
- Corrosive
- Reactive
- Toxic

**Treatment:**
- Incineration
- Chemical treatment
- Secure landfill
- Deep well injection

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Environmental Chemistry Summary

## Pollution Types:

| Type | Key Pollutants |
|------|---------------|
| Air | CO, SO2, NOx, O3, particulates |
| Water | Heavy metals, nutrients, organics |
| Soil | Pesticides, metals, acids |

## Greenhouse Effect:
- CO2, CH4, N2O trap heat
- Enhanced by human activities
- Causes climate change

## Ozone Layer:
- Protects from UV
- CFCs cause destruction
- Montreal Protocol helping recovery

## Acid Rain:
- SO2 + H2O -> H2SO4
- NOx + H2O -> HNO3
- Damages ecosystems, buildings

## Green Chemistry:
- 12 principles
- Prevention over cleanup
- Atom economy
- Safer processes

## Key Solutions:
- Renewable energy
- Pollution control
- Recycling and waste reduction
- Green chemistry principles

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Environmental Chemistry!
